titleStmt.title: Fletcher, John, 1579-1625 / Massinger, Philip, 1583-1640 : : The double marriage (1647)

editionStmt.p: This electronic version was produced at the Centre for Literary and Linguistic Computing at the University of Newcastle by keyboarding from a microfilm printout of an early printed version. It was originally in a format devised in the Centre, with reference panels at the beginning of each line, known as "LILAC". It was subsequently converted by an automated process to a TEI XML format. It lacks the speaker tags provided in the copytext. Contractions and variant spellings of function words have been silently regularised. The text thus lacks information about the original forms of many words and expressions.

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
The double marriage. Genre: Tragedy. Date first published: 1647. Date first performed: 1619-1623.

editorialDecl.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.
Virolet Juliana Brissonet Camillo Ronvere Castruchio Villio Ferrand Pandulfo Boatswain Gunner Duke of Sesse Martia Master Sailor Ascanio Surgeon women servants Boy 1st Guard 1st Sailor 2nd Sailor 2nd Guard 1st Citizen 2nd Citizen Lucio Lawyer Doctor 3rd Citizen Combined voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

sp.l: BOy.
Sir?
If my wife seek me, tell her that
Designs of weight, too heavy for her
knowledge,
Exact my privacy.
I shall, sir.
Do then,
And leave me to myself.
It is a raw morning,
And would you please to interpret that for duty
Which you may construe boldness, I could wish
To arm yourself against it, you would use
More of my service.
I have heat within here,
A noble heat (good boy) to keep it off,
I shall not freeze; deliver my excuse,
And you have done your part.
That is prevented,
My Lady follows you.
Since I must be crossed then,
Let her perform that office.
I obey you.
Prithee to bed; to be thus fond is more tedious
Than if I were neglected.
It is the fault then
Of love and duty which I would fall under,
Rather than want that care which you may challenge
As due to my obedience.
I confess
This tenderness argues a loving wife,
And more deserves my hearts best thanks than anger.
Yet I must tell ye Sweet, you do exceed
In your affection, if you would engross me
To your delights alone.
I am not jealous,
If my embraces have distasted you,
As I must grant you every way so worthy
That it is not in weak woman to deserve you,
Much less in miserable me, that want
Those graces some more fortunate are stored with.
Seek any whom you please, and I will study
With my best service to deserve those favours,
That shall yield you contentment.
You are mistaken.
No, I am patient sir, and so good morrow;
I will not be offensive.
Hear my reasons.
Though in your life a widows bed receives me,
For your sake I must love it. May she prosper
That shall succeed me in it, and your ardour
Last longer to her.
By the love I bear
First to my Countries peace, next to thyself
To whom compared, my life I rate at nothing,
Stood here a Lady that were the choice abstract
Of all the beauties nature ever fashioned,
Or Art gave ornament to, compared, to thee,
Thus as thou art obedient and loving,
I should contemn and loath her.
I do believe ye.
How I am blessed
In my assured belief? this is unfeigned;
And why this sadness then?
Why Juliana,
Believe me, these my sad and dull retirements,
My often, nay almost continued fasts,
Sleep banished from my eyes, all pleasures strangers,
Have neither root nor growth from any cause
That may arrive at woman. Shouldst thou be,
As chastity forbid, false to my bed,
I should lament my fortune, perhaps punish
Thy falsehood, and then study to forget thee:
But that which like a never emptied spring,
Feeds high the torrent of my swelling grief,
Is what my Country suffers; there is a ground
Where sorrow may be planted, and spring up,
Though yielding rage and womanish despair,
And yet not shame the owner.
I do believe it true,
Yet I should think myself a happy woman,
If in this general and timely mourning,
I might or give to you, or else receive
A little lawful comfort.
Thy discretion
In this may answer for me; look on Naples
The Country where we both were born and bred,
Naples the Paradise of Italy,
As that is of the earth; Naples, that was
The sweet retreat of all the worthiest Romans,
When they had shared the spoils of the whole world,
This flourishing Kingdom, whose inhabitants
For wealth and bravery lived like petty kings,
Made subject now to such a tyranny,
As that fair City that received her name
From Constantine the great, now in the power
Of barbarous infidels, may forget her own,
To look with pity on our miseries,
So far in our calamities we transcend her.
For since this Arragonian tyrant Ferrand,
Seized on the government, there is nothing left us
That we can call our own, but our afflictions,
And hardly those; the Kings strange cruelty,
Equals all presidents of Tyranny.
Equal say you:
He has outgone, the worst compared to him;
Nor Phalaris, or Dionisius,
Caligula, nor Nero can be mentioned:
They yet as Kings, abused their regal power;
This as a Merchant, all the Countries fat,
He wholly does engross unto himself;
Our Oils he buys at his own price, then sells them
To us, at dearer rates; our Plate and Jewels,
Under a feigned pretence of public use,
He borrows; which denied, his Instruments force.
The rases of our horses, he takes from us;
Yet keeps them in our pastures; rapes of Matrons,
And Virgins, are too frequent; never man
Yet thanked him for a pardon; for Religion,
It is a thing he dreams not of.
I have heard,
How true it is, I know not; that he sold
The Bishop-prick of Tarent to a Jew,
For thirteen thousand Ducats.
I was present,
And saw the money paid: the day would leave me,
Ere I could number out his impious actions;
Or what the miserable Subject suffers;
And can you entertain in such a time,
A thought of dalliance? tears, and sighs, and groans,
Would better now become you.
They indeed are,
The only weapons, our poor Sex can use,
When we are injured, and they may become us;
But for men that were born free men, of Rank;
That would be registered Fathers of their Country;
And to have on their Tombs in Golden Letters,
The noble style of Tyrant killers, written;
To weep like fools, and women and not like wise men.
To practise a redress, deserves a name,
Which fits not me to give.
Thy grave reproof:
If what thou dost desire, were possible
To be effected? might well argue it,
As wise as loving; but if you consider,
With what strong guards, this Tyrant is defended:
Ruffians, and malcontents drawn from all quarters;
That only know, to serve his impious will;
The Citadels built by him in the neck
Of this poor City; the invincible strength,
Nature by Art assisted, gave this Castle;
And above all his fears admitting no man
To see him, but unarmed; it being death
For any to approach him with a weapon.
You must confess, unless our hands were Canons,
To batter down these walls, our weak breath mines,
To blow his Forts up; or our curses lightning,
To force a passage to him; and then blast him;
Our power is like to yours, and we like you;
Weep our misfortunes.
Walls of Brass resist not
A noble undertaking: nor can vice,
Raise any Bulwark, to make good the place,
Where virtue seeks to enter; then to fall
In such a brave attempt, were such an honour;
That Brutus, did he live again would envy.
Were my dead Father in you, and my Brothers;
Nay, all the Ancestors I am derived from;
As you, in being what you are, are all these.
I had rather wear a mourning Garment for you,
And should be more proud of my widowhood;
You dying for the freedom of this Country;
Than if I were assured, I should enjoy
A perpetuity of life and pleasure,
With you; the Tyrant living.
Till this minute,
I never heard thee speak; O more than woman!
And more to be beloved; can I find out
A Cabinet, to lock a secret in,
Of equal trust to thee? all doubts, and fears,
That scandalise your sex, be far from me;
Thou shalt partake my near and dearest counsels,
And further them with thine.
I will be faithful.
Know then this day, stand heaven propitious to us,
Our liberty begins.
In Ferrands death?
It is plotted love, and strongly, and believe it,
For nothing else could do it; it was the thought,
How to proceed in this design and end it,
That made strange my embraces.
Cursed be she,
That is so indulgent to her own delights,
That for their satisfaction, would give
A stop to such a glorious enterprise:
For me, I would not for the world, I had been
Guilty of such a crime; go on and prosper.
Go on my dearest Lord, I love your Honour
Above my life; nay, yours; my Prayers go with you;
Which I will strengthen with my tears: the wrongs
Of this poor Country, edge your sword; O may it
Pierce deep into this Tyrants heart, and then
When you return bathed in his guilty blood,
I will wash you clean with fountains of true joy.
But who are your assistants? though I am
So covetous of your glory, that I could wish
You had no sharer in it.
Be not curious.
They come, however you command my bosom,
To them I would not have you seen.
I am gon Sir,
Be confident; and may my resolution
Be present with you.
Such a Masculine spirit,
With more than woman's virtues, were a dower
To weigh down a Kings fortune.
Good day to you.
You are an early stirrer.
What new face,
Bring you along?
If I stand doubted Sir?
As by your looks I guess it: you much injure
A man that loves, and truly loves this Country,
With as much zeal as you do; one that hates
The Prince by whom it suffers, and as deadly;
One that dares step as far to gain my freedom,
As any he that breathes; that wears a sword
As sharp as any's.
Nay, no more comparisons.
What you but whisper, I dare speak aloud,
Stood the King by; have means to put in act too
What you but coldly plot; if this deserve then
Suspicion in the best, the boldest, wisest?
Pursue your own intents, I will follow mine;
And if I not out-strip you --
Be assured Sir,
A conscience like this can never be allied
To treachery.
Who durst speak so much,
But one that is like us a sufferer,
And stands as we affected?
You are cozened
And all undone, every Intelligencer
Speaks treason with like licence; is not this
Ronuere, that hath for many years been trained
In Ferrands School, a man in trust and favour,
Rewarded too and highly?
Grant all this,
The thought of what he was, being as he is now;
A man disgraced, and with contempt thrown off;
Will spur him to revenge, as swift as they,
That never were in favour.
Poor and childish.
His regiment is cast, that is most certain;
And his command in the Castle given away.
That on my knowledge.
Grosser still, what shepherd
Would yield the poor remainder of his flock,
To a known wolf; though he put on the habit,
Of a most faithful dog, and bark like one?
As this but only talks.
Yes, he has means too.
I know it to my grief, weak men I know it;
To make his peace, If there were any war
Between him and his Master, betraying
Our innocent lives.
You are too suspicious;
And I have born too much, beyond my temper,
Take you own ways, I will leave you.
You may stay now;
You have enough, and all indeed you fished for;
But one word Gentlemen: have you discovered
To him alone our plot?
To him and others, that are at his devotion.
Worse and worse:
For were he only conscious of our purpose,
Though with the breach of Hospitable laws,
In my own house, I would silence him for ever:
But what is past my help, is past my care,
I have a life to lose.
Have better hopes.
And when you know, with what charge I have furthered
Your noble undertaking, you will swear me
Another man; the guards I have corrupted:
And of the choice of all our noblest youths,
Attired like virgins; such as Hermits would
Welcome to their sad cells, prepared a Mask;
As done for the Kings pleasure.
For his safety
I rather fear; and as a pageant to
Usher our ruin.
We as Torch-bearers
Will wait on these, but with such art and cunning;
I have conveyed sharp poniards in the Wax,
That we may pass, though searched through all his guards
Without suspicion, and in all his glory,
Oppress him, and with safety.
It is most strange.
To be effected.
You are doubtful still.
But we resolved to follow him, and if you
Desist now Virolet, we will say it is fear,
Rather than providence.
And so we leave you,
To your wise doubts, and to my better counsels;
O! pardon me my Lord, and trust me too;
Let me not like Cassandra prophecy truths,
And never be believed, before the mischief!
I have heard all; know this Ronvere a villain;
A villain that hath tempted me, and plotted
This for your ruin, only to make way
To his hopes in my embraces; at more leisure
I will acquaint you, wherefore I concealed it
To this last minute; if you stay you are lost,
And all prevention too late. I know,
And it is to me known only, a dark cave
Within this house, a part of my poor dower,
Where you may lie concealed, as in the centre,
Till this rough blast be over; where there is air,
More than to keep in life; Ferrand will find you,
So curious his fears are.
It is better fall
Than hide my head, now it was thine own advice,
My friends engaged too.
You stand further bound,
Than to weak men that have betrayed themselves,
Or to my Council, though then just and loyal:
Your fancy hath been good, but not your judgment,
In choice of such to side you; will you leap
From a steep Tower, because a desperate fool
Does it, and trusts the wind to save his hazard?
There is more expected from you; all men's eyes are fixed
On Viriolet, to help not hurt them;
Make good their hopes and ours, you have sworn often,
That you dare credit me; and allowed me wise
Although a woman; even Kings in great Actions,
Wait opportunity and so must you Sir,
Or lose your understanding.
Thou art constant;
I am uncertain fool, a most blind fool;
Be thou my guide.
Aye. I fail to direct you,
For torment or reward, when I am wretched,
May constancy forsake me.
I have my safety.
Why are you rapt thus?
Peace, thou art a fool.
But if I were a flatterer like your worship,
I should be wise and rich too;
There are few else that prosper, bawds excepted,
They hold an equal place there.
A shrewd knave;
But O the King, the happy King!
Why happy?
In bearing a great burthen.
What bears he,
That is born on Princes shoulders?
A Crowns weight,
Which sets more heavy on his head, than the ore
Slaves dig out of the Mines, of which it is made.
Thou worthily art his fool, to think that heavy
That carries him in the air; the reverence due
To that most sacred Gold, makes him adored,
His Foot-steps kissed, his smiles to raise a beggar
To a Lords fortune; and when he but frowns,
The City quakes.
Or the poor Cuckolds in it,
Cox-combs I should say, I am of a fool.
Grown a Philosopher, to hear this parasite.
The delicates he is served with see and envy,
I had rather have an Onion with a stomach,
Than these without one.
The Celestial Music,
Such as the motion of the eternal spheres
Yields Ioue, when he drinks Nectar.
Here is a fine knave, yet hath too many fellows.
Then the beauties,
That with variety of choice embraces,
Renew his age.
Help him to crouch rather,
And the French Cringe, they are excellent Surgeons that way.
O Majesty! let others think of heaven,
While I contemplate thee.
This is not Atheism, but Court observance.
Now the God appears, ushered with earth-quakes.
Base Idolatry.

stage.l: Flourish Enter Ferrand, Guard, women, Servants.

sp.l: These meats are poisoned, hang
The Cooks; no note more, on
Forfeit of your fingers; do you
Envy me a minutes slumber, what are these?
The Ladies appointed by your Majesty.
To the purpose, for what appointed?
For your graces pleasure.
To suck away the little blood is left me,
By my continual cares; I am not apt now,
Enjoy them first, taste of my diet once;
And your turn served, for fifty Crowns apiece
Their Husbands may redeem them.
Great Sir, mercy.
I am deaf, why stare you? is what we command
To be disputed? who is this? bring you the dead
To upbraid me to my face?
Hold Emperor;
Hold mightiest of Kings, I am thy vassal,
Thy Foot-stool, that durst not presume to look
On thy offended face.
Castruchio rise.
Let not the lightning of thy eye consume me,
Nor hear that Musical tongue, in dreadful thunder,
That speakest all mercy.
Here is no flattering rogue.
Ferrand, that is the Father of his people,
The glory of mankind.
No more, no word more;
And while I tell my troubles to myself,
Be Statues without motion or voice,
Though to be flattered, is an itch to greatness,
It now offends me.
Here is the happy man;
But speak who dares.
When I was innocent;
I yet remember, I could eat and sleep,
Walk unaffrighted, but now terrible to others:
My guards cannot keep fear from me
It still pursues me; O! my wounded conscience,
The Bed I would rest in, is stuffed with thorns;
The grounds strewed over with adders, and with asps
Wherever I set my foot, but I am in,
And what was got with cruelty, with blood,
Must be defended, though this life is a hell,
I fear a worse hereafter. ha!
My Lord.
Welcome Ronvere, welcome my golden plummet
With which I found mine enemies depths and angers,
Hast thou discovered.
All as you could wish Sir,
The Plot, and the contrivers; was made one
Of the conspiracy.
Is Virolet in?
The head of all, he only scented me:
And from his fear, that I played false is fled;
The rest I have in fetters.
Death and hell.
Next to my mortal foe the pirate Seffe,
I aimed at him; he is virtuous, and wise,
A lover of his freedom and his countries
Dangerous to such as govern by the sword,
And so to me: no tract which way he went,
No means to overtake him?
There is some hope left:
But with a rough hand, to be seized upon.
What is it?
If any know, or where he is,
Or which way he is fled, it is his wife;
Her with his Father I have apprehended,
And brought among the rest.
It was wisely ordered,
Go fetch them in,and let my executioners
Appear in horror with the rack.
I take it seignior, this is no time for you to flatter,
Or me to fool in.
Thou art wise in this, let us off, it is unsafe to be near Jove,
When he begins to thunder.
Good morality.
I that have pierced into the hearts of men;
Forced them to lay open with my looks,
Secrets whose least discovery was death,
Will rend for what concerns my life, the fortress,
Of a weak woman's faith.

stage.l: Enter Ronvere, guard, Executioners with a Rack, Camillo,

sp.l: Whatever we suffer,
The weight, that loads a Traitors
Heart sit ever, heavy on thine.
As we are caught by thee,
Fall thou by others.
Pish poor fools, your curses will
Never reach me.
Now by my Virolets life;
Father, this is a glorious stage of murther.
Here are five properties too, and such spectators,
As will expect good action, to the life;
Let us perform our parts, and we shall live,
When these are rotten, would we might begin once;
Are you the Master of the company?
Troth you are tedious now.
She does deride me.
Thee and thy Power, if one poor syllable
Could win me, an assurance of thy favour,
I would not speak it, I desire to be
The great example of thy cruelty,
To whet which one, know Ferrand, I alone
Can make discovery, where my Virolet is,
Whose life, I know thou aimest at, but if tortures
Compel me to it, may hope of heaven forsake me;
I dare thy worst.
Are we contemned.
Thou art,
Thou and thy Ministers, my life is thine;
But in the death, the Victory shall be mine.
We have such a Mistress here to teach us courage,
That cowards might learn from her.
You are slow;
Begin the Scene thou miserable fool
For so I will make thee.
It is not in thy reach;
I am happy in my sufferings, thou most wretched.
So brave! I will tame you yet, pluck hard villains;
Is she insensible? no sigh nor groan? or is she dead?
No tyrant, though I suffer
More than a woman, beyond flesh and blood;
It is in a cause so honourable, that I scorn
With any sign that may express a sorrow
To show I do repent.
Confess yet,
And thou shall be safe.
It is wrapped up in my soul,
From whence thou canst not force it.
I will be
Ten days akilling thee.
Be twenty thousand,
My glory lives the longer.
It is a miracle,
She tires the executioners,
And me.
Unloose her, I am conquered, I must take
Some other way; reach her my chair, in honour
Of her invincible fortitude.
Will you not
Dispatch the rest?
When I seem merciful,
Assure thyself Ronvere, I am most cruel.
Thou wonder of thy sex, and of this Nation,
That hast changed my severity to mercy,
Not to thyself alone, but to thy people,
In which I do include these men, my enemies:
Unbind them.
This is strange.
For your intent
Against my life, which you dare not deny,
I only ask one service.
Above hope.
There rides a Pirate near, the Duke of Seffe,
My enemy and this Countries, that in bonds
Holds my dear friend Ascanio: free this friend,
Or bring the Pirates head; besides your pardon,
And honour of the action, your reward
Is forty thousand Ducats. And because
I know that Virolet is as bold as wise,
Be he your General, as pledge of your faith,
That you will undertake it: let this old man,
And this most constant Matron stay with me;
Of whom, as of myself, I will be careful;
She shall direct you where her husband is.
Make choice of any ship you think most useful.
They are rigged for you.

stage.l: Exeunt Guard, with Juliana and Pan.

sp.l: We with joy accept it.
And will proclaim King Ferrant merciful.
The mystery of this, my Lord? or are you
Changed in your nature?
I will make thee private to it.
The lives of these weak men, and desperate woman,
Would no way have secured me, had I took them;
It is Virolet I aim at; he has power,
And knows to hurt. If they encounter Seffe,
And he prove conqueror, I am assured
They will find no mercy: if that they prove victors,
I shall recover with my friend; his head
I most desire of all men.
Now I have it.
I will make thee understand the drift of all.
So we stand sure, thus much for those that fall.
Lay here before the wind; up with her Canvas
And let her work, the wind begins to whistle;
Clap all her streamers on, and let her dance,
As if she were the Minion of the Ocean.
Let her bestride the billows till they roar,
And curl their wanton heads. Ho, below there:
Ho, ho, within.
Let her North-east, and thrust her mizzen out,
The day grows fair and clear, and the wind Courts us.
O for a lusty sail now, to give chase to.
A stubborn Bark, that would but bear up to us,
And change a broadside bravely.
Where is the Duke?
I have not seen him stir today.
O Gunner,
What bravery dwells in his age, and what valour?
And to his friends, what gentleness and bounty?
How long have we been inhabitants at Sea here?
Some fourteen years:
By fourteen lives I swear, then,
This Element never nourished such a Pirate;
So great, so fearless, and so fortunate,
So patient in his want, in Act so valiant.
How many sail of well-manned ships before us,
As the Bonuto does the flying fish,
Have we pursued and scowered, that to outstrip us,
They have been fain to hang their very shirts on?
What Galleys have we banged, and sunk, and taken;
Whose only fraughts were fire, and stern defiance?
And nothing spoke but Bullet in all these.
How like old Neptune have I seen our General.
Standing in the Poop, and tossing his still Trident,
Commanding both the Sea and Winds to serve him?
His daughter too, which is the honour, Boteswain,
Of all her sex; that Martial maid.
A brave wench.
How oftentimes, a sight being new begun,
Has she leaped down, and took my Linstock from me,
And crying, now fly right, fired all my chasers?
Then like the Image of the warlike Goddess,
Her Target braced upon her arm, her Sword drawn,
And anger in her eyes, leaped up again,
And bravely haled the Bark. I have wondered Boatswain,
That in a body made so delicate,
So soft for sweet embraces, so much fire,
And manly soul, not starting at a danger.
Her Noble father got her in his fury,
And so she proves a soldier.
This too I wonder at,
Taking so many strangers as he does,
He uses them with that respect and coolness,
Not making prize, but only borrowing
What may supply his want: nor that for nothing;
But renders back what they may stand in need of,
And then parts lovingly: Where, if he take
His Countryman, that should be nearest to him,
And stand most free from danger, he sure pays for it:
He drowns or hangs the men, ransacks the Bark,
Then gives her up a Bonfire to his fortune.
The wrongs he has received from that dull Country,
That is all I know has purchased all his cruelty.
We fare the better; cheerily, cheerily boys,
The ship runs merrily; my Captain is melancholy,
And nothing cures that in him but a Sea-fight:
I hope to meet a sail boy, and a right one.
That is my hope too; I am ready for the pastime.
In the mean time let us bestow a song upon him,
To shake him from his dumps, and bid good day to him.
Ho, in the hold.
Here, here.
To the main top boy.
If thou kenest a ship that dares defy us,
Here is Gold.
I am gon.
Come sirs, a quaint Levet.
To waken our brave General. Then to our labour.

stage.l: Enter Duke of Seffe above and his daughter Martia

sp.l: I thank you loving mates; I thank you all.
There is to prolong your mirths, and good morrow to you.
Take this from me, you are honest valiant friends;
And such we must make much of. Not a sail stirring?
Not any within ken yet.
Without doubt Lady,
The wind standing so fair and full upon us,
We shall have sport anon. But noble General,
Why are you still so sad? you take our edge off;
You make us dull, and spiritless.
I will tell ye,
Because I will provoke you to be fortunate;
For when you know my cause, it will double arm you.
This woman never knew it yet; my daughter,
Some discontents she has.
Pray sir go forward.
These fourteen years, I have stowed it here at Sea,
Where the most curious thought could never find it.
Call up the Master, and all the Mates.

stage.l: Enter below the Master and Saylers.

sp.l: Good morrow.
Good morrow to our General, a good one,
And to that Noble Lady all good wishes.
I thank you Master.
Mark me, thus it is then;
Which I did never think to have discovered,
Till full revenge had wooed me; but to satisfy
My faithful friends, thus I cast off my burden.
In that short time I was a Courtier,
And followed that most hated of all Princes,
Ferrant the full example of all mischiefs,
Compelled to follow to my soul a stranger,
It was my chance one day to play at Chess
For some few Crowns, with a minion of this Kings,
A mean poor man, that only served his pleasures;
Removing of a Rook, we grew to words;
From this to hotter anger: to be short,
I got a blow.
How, how my Noble father?
A blow my girl, which I had soon repaid,
And sunk the slave for ever, had not odds
Thrust in betwixt us. I went away disgraced --
For honours sake not so sir.
For that time, wench;
But called upon him, like a Gentleman,
By many private friends; knocked at his valour,
Courted his honour hourly to repair me;
And though he were a thing my thought made sleight on,
And only worth the fury of my footman,
Still I pursued him Nobly.
Did he escape you?
My old brave father, could you sit down so coldly?
Have patience, and know all. Pursued him fairly,
Till I was laughed at, scorned, my wrongs made may-games.
By him unjustly wronged, should be all justice,
To slave protected; yet at length I found him,
Found him, when he supposed all had been buried;
And what I had received durst not be questioned:
And then he fell, under my Sword he fell,
For ever sunk; his poor life, like the air,
Blown in an empty bubble, burst, and left him,
No Noble wind of memory to raise him.
But then began my misery, I fled;
The Kings frowns following, and my friends despairs;
No hand that durst relieve: my Country fearful,
Basely and weakly fearful of a tyrant;
Which made his bad will worse, stood still and wondered,
Their virtues bedridden in them; then my girl,
A little one, I snatched thee from thy nurse,
The model of thy fathers miseries:
And some small wealth was fit for present carriage,
And got to Sea; where I professed my anger,
And will do, whilst that base ungrateful Country,
And that bad King, have blood or means to quench me.
Now ye know all.
We know all, and admire all;
Go on and do all still, and still be fortunate.
Had you done less, or lost this Noble anger,
You had been worthy then men's empty piddles,
And not their wonders. Go on, and use your justice;
And use it still with that fell violence
It first appeared to you; if you go less,
Or take a doting mercy to protection,
The honour of a father I disclaim in you,
Call back all duty, and will be prouder of
The infamous and base name of a whore,
Than daughter to a great Duke and a coward.
Mine own sweet Martia, no; thou knowest my nature,
It cannot, must not be.
I hope it shall not.
But why sir, do you keep alive still young Ascanio,
Prince of Rossana, King Ferrants most beloved one,
You took two months ago?
Why is not he flung overboard, or hanged?
I will tell thee girl:
It were a mercy in my nature now,
So soon to break the bed of his afflictions;
I am not so far reconciled yet to him
To let him die, that were a benefit.
Besides, I keep him as a bait and diet,
To draw on more, and nearer to the King,
I look each hour to hear of his Armados,
And a hot welcome they shall have.
But hark you?
If you were overswayed with odds --
I find you:
I would not yield; no girl, no hope of yielding,
Nor fling myself one hour into their mercies,
And give the tyrant hope to gain his Kingdom.
No, I can sink wench, and make shift to die;
A thousand doors are open, I shall hit one.
I am no niggard of my life, so it go Nobly:
All ways are equal and all hours; I care not.
Now you speak like my father.
Noble General,
If by our means they inherit aught but bangs,
The mercy of the main yard light upon us.
No, we can sink too sir, and sink low enough,
To pose their cruelties, to follow us:
And he that thinks of life, if the world go that way,
A thousand cowards suck his bones.
Let the worst come,
I can unbreech a Canon, and without much help
turn her into the Keel; and when she has split it,
Every man knows his way, his own prayers,
And so good night I think.
We have lived all with you,
And will die with you General.
I thank you Gentlemen.
A Sail, a Sail.
A cheerful sound.
A Sail.
Of whence? of whence boy?
A lusty sail.
Look right, and look again.
She ploughs the Sea before her,
And foams in the mouth.
Of whence?
I ken not yet sir.
O may she prove of Naples.
Prove the Devil,
We will spit out fire as thick as she.
Hoy.
Brave boy.
Of Naples Naples, I think of Naples, Master,
Methinks I see the Arms.
Up, up another,
And give more certain signs.
All to your business,
And stand but right and true
Hang him that halts now.
She has us in chase.
We will spare her our main top-sail,
He shall not look us long, we are no starters.
Down with the fore-sail too, we will spoon before her.
Gunner, good noble Gunner, for my honour
Load me but these two Minions in the chape there;
And load them right, that they may bid fair welcome,
And be thine eye and level as thy heart is.
Madam, I will scratch them out, I will piss them out else.
Ho.
Of whence now?
Of Naples, Naples, Naples.
I see her top flag how she quarters Naples.
I hear her Trumpets.
Down, she is welcome to us.
Every man to his charge, man her in the bow well.
And place your rakers right, daughter be sparing.
I swear I will be above sir, in the thickest,
And where most danger is, I will seek for honour.
They have begun, hark how their Trumpets call us.
Hark how the wide mouthed Cannons sing amongst us.
Hark how they sail; out of our shells for shame sir.
Now fortune and my cause.
Be bold and conquer.
They will board us once again; they are tough and valiant.
Twice we have blown them into the air like feathers.
And made them dance.
Good boys, fight bravely, manly.
They come on yet; clap in her stern, and yoke them.
You shall not need, I have provision for them;
Let them board once again, the next is ours.
Stand bravely to your Pikes, away, be valiant.
I have a second course of service for them,
Shall make the bowels of their Bark ache, hoy
The Duke fights like a Dragon. Who dares be idle.
Down with them, stow them in.
Cut their throats, it is brotherhood to fling them into the Sea.
The Duke is hurt, so is his lovely daughter Martia.
We have the day yet.
Pox fire them, they have smoked us, never such plumbs yet flew.
They have rent the ship, and bored a hundred holes,
She swims still lustily.
She made a brave fight, and she shall be cured,
And make a braver yet.
Bring us some Cans up, I am hot as fire.
I am sure I am none of the coolest.
My Cannons rung like Bells. Here is to my Mistress.
The dainty Sweet brass Minion, split their fore-mast, ,
She never failed.
Ye did all well, and truly, like faithful honest men.
But is she rich Master?
Rich for my Captains purpose howsoever,
And we are his. How bravely now he shows,
Heated in blood and anger? how do you sir?
Not wounded mortally I hope?
No Master, but only wear the livery of fury.
I am hurt, and deep.
My Mistress too?
A scratch man,
My needle would have done as much good sir,
Be provident and careful.
Prithee peace girl,
This wound is not the first blood I have blushed in,
Ye fought all like tall men, my thanks among ye,
That speaks not what my purse means, but my tongue,
soldiers.
Now sir, to you that sought me out, that found me,
That found me what I am, the Tyrants Tyrant;
You that were imped the weak arm to his folly,
You are welcome to your death.
I do expect it,
And therefore need no complement, but wait it.
Thou borest the face once of a Noble Gentleman,
Ranked in the first style of the virtuous,
By every hopeful spirit, showed and pointed,
Thy Countries love; one that advanced her honour,
Not tainted with the base and servile uses
The Tyrant ties men's souls too. Tell me Virolet,
If shame have not forsook thee, with thy credit.
No more of these Racks; what I am I am.
I hope not to go free with poor confessions;
Nor if I show ill, will I seem a monster,
By making my mind prisoner; do your worst.
When I came out to deal with you, I cast it,
Only those base inflictions fit for slaves,
Because I am a Gentleman.
Thou art none.
Thou wast while thou stoodest good, thou art now a villain
And agent for the devil.
That tongue lies.
Give me my Sword again, and stand all armed;
I will prove it on ye all, I am a Gentleman,
A man as fair in honours; rate your prisoners;
How poor and like a Pedagogue it shows?
How far from Nobleness? it is fair, you may kill us;
But to defame your victory with foul language.
Go, fling him overboard; I will teach you sirrah.
You cannot teach me to die. I could kill you now
With patience, in despising all your cruelties.
And make you choke with anger.
Away I say.
Stay sir, he has given you such bold language,
I am not reconciled to him yet, and therefore
He shall not have his wish observed so nearly,
To die when he please; I beseech you stay sir.
Do with him what thou wilt.
Carry him to the Bilboes,
And clap him fast there, with the Prince.
Do Lady,
For any death you give, I am bound to bless you.
Now to your Cabin, sir; pray lean upon me,
And take your rest, the Surgeons wait all for you.
Thou makest me blush to see thee bear thy fortunes;
Why, sure I have no hurt, I have not fought sure?
You bleed apace, Sir.
Ye grow cold too.
I must be ruled, no leaning,
My deepest wounds scorn Crutches.
A brave General.
Will they not moore her?
Not till we come to the Fort,
This is too weak a place for our defences,
The Carpenters are hard at work; she swims well,
And may hold out another fight. The ship we took
Burns there to give us light.
She made a brave fight.
She put us all in fear.
Beshrew my heart did she.
Her men are gone to Candy, they are peppered,
All but this prisoner.
Sure he is a brave fellow.
A stubborn knave, but we have pulled his bravery.

stage.l: He discovers Virolet and Ascanio in the Bilboes.

sp.l: Look how he looks now: come let us go serve his diet,
Which is but bread and water.
He will grow fat on it.
I must confess I have endured much misery,
even almost to the ruin of my spirit,
But ten times more grows my affliction,
To find my friend here.
Had we served our Country,
Or honesties, as we have served our follies,
We had not been here now?
It is too true Virolet.
And yet my end in venturing for your safety,
Pointed at more than Ferrants will, a base one;
Some service for mine own, some for my Nation,
Some for my friend; but I am rightly paid,
That durst adventure such a Noble office,
From the most treacherous command of mischief;
You know him now?
And when I nearer knew him,
Than when I waited, Heaven be witness with me,
(And if I lie my miseries still load me)
With what tears I have wooed him, with what prayers,
What weight of reasons I have laid, what dangers;
Then, when the peoples curses flew like storms;
And every tongue was whetted to defame him,
To leave his doubts, his tyrannies, his slaughters,
His fell oppressions. I know I was hated too.
And all mankind that knew him: these confessions
Do no good to the world, to Heaven they may.
Let us study to die well, we have lived like coxcombs.
That my misfortune, should lose you too.
Yes;
And not only me, but many more, and better:
For my life, it is not this; or might I save yours,
And some brave friends I have engaged, let me go;
It were the meritorious death I wish for,
But we must hang or drown like whelps.
No remedy.
On my part I expect none. I know the man,
And know he has been nettled to the quick too,
I know his nature.
A most cruel nature.
His wrongs have bred him up. I cannot blame him.
He has a daughter too, the greatest scorner,
And most insulting upon misery.
For those, they are toys to laugh at, not to lead men:
A woman's mirth or anger, like a meteor
Glides and is gone, and leaves no crack behind it;
Our miseries would seem like masters to us,
And shake our manly spirits into fevers,
If we respected those; the more they glory,
And raise insulting Trophies on our ruins;
The more our virtues shine in patience.
Sweet Prince, the name of death was never terrible
To him that knew to live; nor the loud torrent
Of all afflictions, singing as they swim,
A gall of heart, but to a guilty conscience:
Whilst we stand fair, but by a two-edged storm,
We find untimely falls, like early Roses;
But to the earth, we bear our native sweetness.
Good sir go on.
When we are little children,
And cry and fret for every toy comes cross us;
How sweetly do we show, when sleep steals on us?
When we grow great, but our affections greater,
And struggle with this stubborn twin, born with us;
And tug and pull, yet still we find a Giant:
Had we not then the privilege to sleep,
Our everlasting sleep? he would make us idiots;
The memory and monuments of good men
Are more than lives, and though their Tombs want tongues,
Yet have they eyes, that daily sweat their losses;
And such a tear from stone, no time can value.
To die both young and good, are natures curses,
As the world says; ask truth, they are bounteous blessings:
For then we reach at Heaven, in our full virtues,
And fix ourselves new Stars, crowned with our goodness.
You have double armed me.
Hark, what noise is this?
What horrid noise is the Sea pleased to sing,
A hideous Dirge to our deliverance?
Stand fast now.

stage.l: Within strange cries, horrid noyse, Trumpets.

sp.l: I am fixed.
We fear ye not.
Let death appear in all shapes, we smile on him.
The Lady now.
The face of the Mask is altered.
What will she do?
Do what she can, I care not.
She looks on you sir.
Rather she looks through me,
But yet she stirs me not.
Poor wretched slaves,
Why do you live? or if ye hope for mercy,
Why do not you howl out, and fill the hold
With lamentations, cries, and base submissions,
Worthy our scorn?
Madam, you are mistaken;
We are no slaves to you, but to blind fortune;
And if she had her eyes, and durst be certain,
Certain our friend, I would not bow unto her;
I would not cry, nor ask so base a mercy:
If you see anything, in our appearance,
Worthy your sexes softness and your own glory?
Do it for that; and let that good reward it:
We cannot beg.
I will make you beg, and bow too.
Madam for what?
For life; and when you hope it,
Then will I laugh and triumph on your baseness.
Madam it is true, there may be such a favour,
And we may ask it too; ask it with honour;
And thank you for that favour, nobly thank you,
Though it be death; but when we beg a base life,
And beg it of your scorn --
You are cozened woman,
Your handsomeness may do much, but not this way;
but for your glorious hate --
Are ye so stubborn?
Death, I will make you bow.
It must be in your bed then;
There you may work me to humility.
Why, I can kill thee.
If you do it handsomely;
It may be I can thank you, else --
So glorious?
Her cruelty now works.
Yet wilt thou?
No.
Wilt thou for life sake?
No, I know your subtlety.
For honour sake?
I will not be a Pageant,
My mind was ever firm, and so I will lose it.
I will starve thee to it.
I will starve myself, and cross it.
I will lay thee on such miseries --
I will wear them,
And with that wantonness, you do your Bracelets.
I will be a month akilling thee.
Poor Lady,
I will be a month adying then: what is that?
There is many a Calenture outdoes your cruelty.
How might I do, in killing of his body,
To save his Noble mind? Who waits there?

stage.l: Enter a Saylor with a rich Cap and Mantle.

sp.l: Madam,
Unbolt this man, and leave those things behind you,
And so away. Now put them on. Unbolt him.
To what end?
To my end, to my will.
I will.
I thank you.
Nay, now you thank me, I will do more. I will tell ye,
I am a servant to your courtesy,
And so far will be wooed: but if this triumph
Be only aimed, to make your mischief glorious;
Lady, you have put a richer shroud upon me,
Which my strong mind shall suffer in.
Come hither,
And all thy bravery put into thy carriage,
For I admire thee.
Whither will this woman?
Take heed my friend.
Look as thou scornedest my cruelty:
I know thou dost.
I never feared, now flattered.
No if thou hadst, thou hadst died, and I had gloried.
I suffer now, and thou which art my prisoner,
Hast Nobly won the free power to despise me.
I love thee, and admire thee for thy Nobleness;
And for thy manly sufferance, am thy servant.
Good Lady, mock me not.
By Heaven I love thee;
And by the soul of love, am one piece with thee.
Thy mind, thy mind; thy brave, thy manly mind:
That like a Rock stands all the storms of fortune,
And beats them roaring back they cannot reach thee:
That lovely mind I dote on, not the body;
That mind has robbed me of my liberty:
That mind has darkened all my bravery,
And into poor despised things, turned my angers.
Receive me to your love sir, and instruct me;
Receive me to your bed, and marry me:
I will wait upon you, bless the hour I knew you.
Is this a new way?
If you doubt my faith.
First take your liberty; I will make it perfect,
Or anything within my power.
I love you;
But how to recompense your love with marriage?
Alas, I have a wife.
Dearer than I am?
That will adventure so much for your safety?
Forget her fathers wrongs, quit her own honour,
Pull on her for a strangers sake, all curses?
Shall this Prince have his freedom too?
Else all I love is gone, all my friends perish.
He shall.
What shall I do?
If thou despise my courtesy,
When I am dead for grief I am forsaken,
And no soft hand left to assuage your sorrows;
Too late, but too true, curse your own cruelties.
Be wise; if she be true, no thread is left else,
To guide us from this labyrinth of mischief;
Nor no way for our friends.
Thus then, I take you:
I bind ye to my life, my love.
I take you,
And with the like bond tie my heart your servant;
We are now almost at Harbour, within this hour,
In the dead watch, I will have the long-boat ready;
And when I give the word, be sure you enter,
I will see ye furnished both immediately,
And like yourself; some trusty man shall wait you,
The watch I will make mine own; only my love
Requires a stronger vow, which I will administer
Before we go.
I will take it to confirm you.
Go in, there are the Keys, unlock his fetters,
And arm ye Nobly both; I will be with you presently,
And so this loving kiss.
Be constant Lady.

stage.l: Enter the Duke of Seffe by Torchlight, Master and

sp.l: You grow so angry sir, your wound goes backward.
I am angry at the time, at none of you,
That sends but one poor subject for revenge;
I would have all the Court and all the villainy,
Was ever practised under that foul Ferrand
Tyrant, and all to quench my wrath.
Be patient,
Your grace may find occasion every hour,
For certain they will seek you, to satisfy,
And to the full, your anger.
Death, they dare not:
They know that I command death, feed his hunger,
And when I let him loose --
You will never heal sir,
If these extremes dwell in you, you are old,
And burn your spirits out with this wild angers.
Thou liest, I am not old, I am as lusty
And full of manly heat as them, or thou art.
No more of that.
And dare seek out a danger;
And hold him at the swords point, when thou tremblest
And creepest into thy box of salves to save thee.
O Master, I have had a dreadful dream tonight!
Me-thought the ship was all on fire, and my loved
Daughter,
To save her life, leapt into the Sea; where suddenly
A stranger snatched her up, and swam away with her.
It was but the heat of the fight sir.
Look out, what is that?
The long-boat as I live.
Ho, there, in the long-boat.

stage.l: She claps on all her Oares.

sp.l: What noise is that?
I hear sir --
The devil or his dam; hail her again boys.
The long-boat, ho, the long-boat.
Why, the long-boat?
Where is the long-boat?
She is stolen off.
Who stole her?
O my prophetic soul!
You daughter is gone sir;
The prisoners, and six sailors, rogues.
Mischief, six thousand plagues sale with them;
They are in her yet, make out.
We have never a Boat.
Who knew of this trick?
Weigh Anchors and away.
We have no wind sir,
They will beat us with their Oars.
Then sink them Gunner,
O sink them, sink them, sink them, claw them Gunner;
As ever thou hast loved me.
I will do reason,
But I will be hanged before I hurt the Lady.
Who knew of this?

stage.l: Trump. a peece or two go off.

sp.l: We stand all clear.
What devil
Put this base trick into her tail? my daughter,
And run away with rogues! I hope she is sunk,
Or torn to pieces with the short; rots find her,
The leprosy of whore, stick ever to her,
O she has ruined my revenge.
She is gone sir,
I cannot reach her with my shot.
Rise winds, blow till you burst the air,
Blow till ye burst the air, and swell the Seas,
That they may sink the stars, O dance her, dance her;
She is impudently wanton, dance her, dance her,
Mount her upon your surges, cool her, cool her
She runs hot like a whore, cool her, cool her;
O now a shot to sink her; come, cut Cables;
I will away, and where she sets her foot
Although it be in Ferrants court, I will follow her,
And such a fathers vengeance shall she suffer --
Dare any man stand by me?
All, all.
All sir.
And the same cup you taste.
Cut Cables then;
For I shall never sleep, nor know what peace is,
Till I have plucked her heart out;
O main there.

stage.l: Enter Ferrant, Ronvere, Castruchio, Villo, and

sp.l: You are too gentle sir.
You are too careless:
The creatures I have made, no way regard me:
Why should I give you names, titles of honour
Rob families, to fill your private houses
For your advancement, draw all curses on me,
Wake tedious winter nights, to make them happy
That for me break no slumber?
What we can,
We dare do
Why is your Sovereigns life then
(In which you live, and in whose fall your honours,
Your wealth, your pomp, your pride and all must suffer)
No better guarded? O my cruel Stars,
That mark me out a King, raising me on
This pinnacle of greatness, only to be
The nearer blasting!
What think you now Castruchio?
Is not this a merry life?
Still thou art cozened;
It is a glorious royal discontentment;
How bravely it becomes him!
To be made
The common butt, for every slave to shoot at;
No peace, no rest I take, but their alarums
Beat at my heart: why do I live, or seek then,
To add a day more to these glorious troubles?
Or to what end when all I can arrive at,
Is but the summing up of fears and sorrows,
What power has my command, when from my bosom
Ascanio my most dear, and loved Ascanio,
Was snatched, spite of my will, spite of my succour,
And by mine own proud slave retained most miserable,
And still that villains lives to nip my pleasures,
It being not within my power to reach him.
Time may restore all this; and would you hear
Whose counsel never failed you.
Tell me no more,
I faint beneath the burthen of my cares,
And yield myself most wretched.
O my Knees
I beg it might sir, vouchsafe me hearing.
Speak, speak, and I thus low, such is my fortune,
Will hear what thou canst say.
Look but on this,
Has not a man that has but means to keep
A Hawk, a Greyhound, and a hunting Nag,
More pleasure than this King?
A dull fool still,
Make me a King, and let me scratch with care,
And see who will have the better; give me rule,
Command, obedience, pleasure of a King,
And let the devil roar; The greatest corrosive
A King can have, is of more precious tickling,
And handled to the height more dear delight,
Than other men's whole lives, let them be safe too.
Think of the mutinous people.
Hang the people,
Give me the pleasure, let me do all, awe all,
Enjoy their wives and states at my discretion,
And peg them when I please, let the slaves mumble.
But say they should be vexed, and rise against thee?
Let them rise, let them rise: give me the bridle here,
And see if they can crack my girths: ah Villio,
Under the Sun, there is nothing so voluptuous
As riding of this monster, till he founder.
Who is that so loud?
I am dumb: is not this rare?
Kings looks make Pythagoreans; is not this
A happiness Villio?
Yes, to put to silence
A fawning sycophant.
Thou speakest truth in all,
And mercy is a vice, when there needs rigour,
Which I with all severity will practise:
And since as subjects they pay not obedience,
They shall be forced as slaves: I will remove
Their means to hurt, and with the means, my fears:
Go you the fatal executioners
Of my commands, and in our name proclaim,
That from this hour I do forbid all meetings,
All private conferences in the City:
To feast a neighbour shall be death; to talk,
As they meet in the streets, to hold discourse,
By writing, nay by signs; see this performed,
And I will call your cruelty, to those
That dare repine at this, to me true service.
This makes for us.
Aye now we have employments.
If we grow not rich it were fit we should be beggars.
Ronvere.
My Lord.
Thou enemy to Majesty?
What thinkst thou of a Kingdom?
As of a man
That hath power to do ill.
Of a thing rather
That does divide an Empire with the Gods;
Observe but with how little breath he shakes
A populous City, which would stand unmoved
Against a whirlwind.
Then you make him more
Than him that rules the winds.
For me I do profess it,
Were I offered to be anything on Earth,
I would be mighty Ferrant.
Ha? who names me?
Deliver thy thoughts slave, thy thoughts and truly,
Or be no more.
They rather will deserve.
Your favour than your fury; I admire,
(As who does not, that is a loyal subject?)
Your wisdom, power, your perfect happiness,
The most blessed of mankind.
Didst thou but feele
The weighty sorrows, that sit on a Crown,
Though thou shouldest find one in the streets Castruchio,
Thou wouldst not think it worth the taking up;
But since thou art enamoured of my fortune,
Thou shalt ere long taste of it.
But one day,
And then let me expire.
Go to my wardrobe,
And of the richest things I wear, cull out,
What thou thinkst fit: do you attend him sirrah.
I warrant you, I shall be at his elbow,
The fool will never leave him.
Made for ever.
What shout is that? draw up Guards.
Those rather

stage.l: En. Virolet, Ascanio, and a servant.

sp.l: Speak joy then danger.
Bring her to my house,
I would not have her seen here.
My Ascanio!
The most desired of all the men, let me die
In these embraces; how wert thou redeemed?
Sir, this is my preserver.
At more leisure,
I will inquire the manner, and the means,
I cannot spare so much time now from my
More strict embraces: Virolet, welcome too,
This service weighs down your intended treason;
You long have been mine enemy, learn now
To be my friend and loyal, I ask no more,
And live as free as Ferrant; let him have
The forty thousand crowns I gladly promised,
For my Ascanios freedom, and deliver
His Father, and his wife to him in safety,
Something hath passed which I am sorry for,
But it will not now be helped; come my Ascanio,
And reap the harvest of my winter travels.
My best Ascanio, my most loved Ascanio.
My Lord, all former passages forgot,
I am become a suitor.
To me Virolet?
To you, yet will not beg the courtesy,
But largely pay you for it.
To the purpose.
The forty thousand crowns the King hath given me,
I will bestow on you, if by your means
I may have liberty for a divorce
Between me and my wife.
Your Julieana?
That for you hath endured so much, so nobly?
The more my sorrow; but it must be so.
I will not hinder it: without a bribe,
For mine own ends, I would have furthered this.
I will use all my power.
It is all I ask:
O my cursed fate, that ever man should hate
Himself for being beloved, or be compelled
To cast away a Jewel, Kings would buy,
Though with the loss of Crown and Monarchy!
How do I look?
You are so strangely altered.
We scarce know you, so young again, and utterly
From that you were, figure, or any favour;
Your friends cannot discern you.
I have none,
None but my fair revenge, and let that know me;
You are finely altered too.
To please your humour,
But we may pass without disguise, our living
Was never in their element.
This Jew sure,
That altered you, is a made knave.
O! a most excellent fellow.
How he has mewed your head, has rubbed the show off,
And run your beard into a peak of twenty!
Stopped all the crannies in your face.
Most rarely.
And now you look as plump, your eyes as sparkling,
As if you were to leap into a Ladies saddle.
Has he not set your nose awry?
The better.
I think it be the better, but it is awry sure;
North and by East. Aye there is the point it stands in;
Now half a point to the Southward.
I could laugh,
But that my business requires no mirth now;
Thou art a merry fellow.
I would the Jew sir,
Could steer my head right, for I have such a swimming in it,
Ever since I went to Sea first.
Take wine and purge it.
I have had a thousand pills of Sack, a thousand;
A thousand pottle pills.
Take more.
Good Doctor,
Your patient is easily persuaded.
The next fair open weather
Methinks this Jew,
If he were truly known to foundered Courtiers,
And decayed Ladies, that have lost their fleeces
On every bush, he might pick a pretty living.
The best of all our gallants, now be glad of him;
For if you mark their marches, they are tender,
Soft, soft, and tender; then but observe their bodies,
And you shall find them cemented by a Surgeon,
Or some Physician for a year or two,
And then to the tub again, for a new pickle.
This Jew might live a Gentile here.

stage.l: Ent. 2. Citizens at both dores, saluting afar off.

sp.l: What are these?
Stand close and mark?
These are no men, they are motions.
What sad and ruthful faces!
How they duck!
This senseless, silent courtesy methinks,
Shows like two Turkes, saluting one another,
Upon two French porters backs.
They are my Countrymen,
And this, some forced infliction from the tyrant;
What are you? why is this? why move thus silent
As if you were wandering shadows? why so sad?
Your tongues sealed up; are ye of several Countries?
You understand not one another?
That is an English man,
He looks as though he has lost his dog.
Your habits
Show ye all Neapolitanes, and your faces
Deliver you oppressed things: speak boldly:
Do you groan, and labour under this stiff yoke?
They shake their heads and weep.
O misery!
Give plenteous sorrow, and not tongues to show them!
This is a studied cruelty.
Be gon sir,
It seems you are a stranger and yourself;
You wonder here at us, as much we wonder
To hear you speak so openly, and boldly,
The Kings command being published to the contrary;
It is death here, above two to talk together;
And that must be but common salutation neither,
Short and so part.
How should a man buy mustard,
If he be forced stay the making of it?
Clear all the streets before the King:
Get off Sir,
And shift as we must do.
I will see his glory.
Stand fast now and like men,

stage.l: En. Castrucrio like the King, in the midst of a gard.

sp.l: Begin the game sir,
And pluck me down, the Row
Of houses there.
They hide the view of the hill; and sink those merchants,
Their ships are foul and stink.
This is a sweet youth.
All that are taken in assemblies,
Their houses and their wives, their wealths are forfeit,
Their lives at your devotion. Villains, Knaves,
I will make you bow and shake, I will make you kneel Rogues.
How brave it is to be a King?
Here is fine tumbling.
No man shall sit in the temple near another.
Nor lie with his own wife.
All upon pain
Of present death, forget to write
That is excellent,
Carriers and foot-Posts, will be arrant Rebels.
No Character, or stamp that may deliver
This man's intention, to that man in the Country.
Nay, if you cut off, after my hearty commendations
Your friend and Oliver. No more.
No man smile,
And wear a face of mirth; that fellow is coming,
And hides a double heart, he is your prize, smoke him.

stage.l: Enter Virolet, Ronvero, Ascanio, and Martia.

sp.l: What base abuse is this? Ha? it is her face sure,
My prisoners with her too? by heaven wild whore
Now is my time.
Do what you will.
Stay hold yet.
My country shall be served first, let her go,
We will have an hour for her to make her tremble.
Now show yourselves, and bless you with your valours.
Here is a whole plump of Rogues.
Now for your Country.
Away with them and hang them; no, no mercy,
I say no mercy.
Be it so upon them.
Treason, treason, treason.
Cut the slaves to giggets.
Down with the bull-beefs.
Hold, hold, I command you -- look here
A miserable thing I am no King sir.
Sirrah, your fools face has preserved your life.
Wear no more Kings coats, you have scaped a scouring.
Is it not the King.
No, it is a prating Rascal,
The puppy makes him mirth.
Yes sir, I am a puppy.
I beseech you let me hang him,
I will do it in my belt straight.
As you are honourable,
It is enough you may hang me.
I will hang a squib at his tail
That shall blow both his buttocks, like a petard.
Do anything.
But do not kill me Gentlemen.
Let us flea him, and have him fly blown.
Away, and save your lives.
The King himself is coming on; if you stay,
You are lost for ever; let not so much nobleness
Wilfully perish.
How near?
He is here behind you.
We thank you.
Double the Guards and take in men that dare,
These slaves are frighted; where are the proud Rebels,
To what protection fled, what villain leads them?
Under our nose disturb our rest?
We shall hear,
For such a search I have sent, to hunt the Traitors.
Yet better men I say, we stand too open:
How now Castruchio? how do you like our glory?
I must confess, it was somewhat more than my match Sir;
This open glory agrees not with my body,
But if it were in the Castle, or some strength,
Where I might have my swing.
You have been swinged brother;
How these delights have tickled you? you itch yet;
Will you walk out again in pomp?
Good Fool.
These rogues must be rebuked, they are too saucy,
These peremptory Knaves. Will you walk out Sir,
And take the remnant of your Coronation?
The people stay to see it.
Do not vex him;
Has grief enough in his bones; you shall to the Citadel,
And like myself command, there use your pleasure,
But take heed to your person.
The more danger;
Still the more honour Brother.
If I reign not then,
And like a King, and thou shalt know it fool,
And thou shalt feel it fool.
Fools still are freemen,
I will sue for a protection, till thy reign is out.
The people have abused the liberty
I late allowed, I now proclaim it straighter,
No men shall walk together, nor salute;
For they that do shall die.
You hit the right Sir;
That liberty cut off, you are free from practise.
Renew my guards.
I shall.
And keep strict watches;
One hour of joy I ask.
You shall have many.

stage.l: Pandulfo, and Iuliana, led by two of the guard,

sp.l: You are not at liberty, in your own house Lady,
And here our charge takes end.
It is now a Custom.
We must even woo those men deserve worst of us,
And so we thank your labours; there is to drink,
For that, and mischief are your occupations;
And to mean well to no man, your Chiefest harvests.
You give liberally; we hope Sir, ere it be long,
To be oftener acquainted with your bounty,
And so we leave you.
Do, for I dote not on ye;
But where is my Husband? what should I do here?
Or what share have I in this joy, called liberty,
Without his company? Why did you flatter me,
And tell me he was returned, his service honoured?
He is so, and stands high in the Kings favour,
His friends redeemed, and his own liberty,
From which yours is derived, confirmed; his service,
To his own wish rewarded: so fare-well Lady.
Go persecute the good, and hunt ye hell-hounds;
Ye Leeches of the time, suck till ye burst slaves;
How does my girl?
Weak yet, but full of comfort;
Sit down, and take some rest;
My heart is whole Father;
That joys, and leaps, to hear my Virolet,
My Deer, my life, has conquered his afflictions.
Those rude hands, and that bloody will that did this,
That durst upon thy tender body Print
These Characters of cruelty; hear me heaven.
O Sir be sparing.
I will speak it, though I burst;
And though the air had ears, and served the Tyrant,
Out it should go: O hear me thou great Justice;
The miseries, that wait upon their mischiefs,
Let them be numberless, and no eye pity
Them when their souls are laden, and in labour,
And wounded through, and through, with guilt and horror,
As mine is now with grief; let men laugh at them
Then, when their monstrous sins, like earthquake, shake them;
And those eyes, that forgot heaven would look upward,
The bloody alarms, of the conscience beating,
Let mercy fly, and day struck into darkness,
Leave their blind souls, to hunt out their own horrors.
Enough, enough, we must forget dear Father;
For then we are glorious forms of heaven; and live,
When we can suffer, and as soon forgive.
But where is my Lord? methinks I have seen this house,
And have been in it before.
Thine own house jewel.
Mine, without him? or his, without my company?
I think it cannot be; it was not wont Father.
Some business with the King (let it be good heaven)
Retains him sure.
It must be good and noble,
For all men that he treats with taste of virtue;
His words and actions are his own; and Honour is
Not bought, nor compelled from him.
Here is the Boy.
He can confirm us more, how sad the child looks?
Come hither Lucio; how, and where is thy Master?
Speak gentle Boy.
Is he returned in safety?
If not, and that thou knowest is miserable,
Our hopes and happiness declined for ever;
Study a sorrow, excellent as thy Master,
Then if thou canst live, leave us.
Noble Madam,
My Lord is safe returned, safe to his friends, and fortune,
Safe to his Country, entertained with honour,
Is here within the house.
Do not mock me.
But such a melancholy hangs on his mind,
And in his eyes inhabit such sad shadows;
But what the cause is --
Go tell him we are here Boy,
There must be no cause now.
Hast thou forgot me?
No, noblest Lady.
Tell him I am here,
Tell him his wife is here, sound my name to him,
And thou shalt see him start; speak Iuliana,
And like the Sun that labours through a tempest,
How suddenly he will disperse his sadness?
Go I command thee instantly,
And charge him on his duty.
On his Love Boy:
I would fain go to him.
Away, away, you are foolish.
Bear all my service sweet Boy.
Art thou here still?
And tell him what thou wilt that shall become thee.
In the house; and know we are here.
No, no, he did not;
I warrant you he did not: could you think
His Love had less than wings, had he but seen me;
His strong affection anything but fire
Consuming all weak lets, and rubs before it,
Till he had met my flame, and made one body?
If ever heavens high blessings met in one man,
And there erected to their holy uses
A sacred mind, fit for their services,
Built all of polished honour, it was in this man:
Misdoubt him not.
I know he is truly noble;
But why this sadness, when the general cause
Requires a Jubilee of joy?
I know not.
Pray heaven you find it not.
I hope I shall not:
O here he comes, and with him all my happiness;
He stays and thinks, we may be too unmannerly;
Pray give him leave.
I do not like this sadness.
O hard condition of my misery!
Unheard-of plagues! when to behold that woman,
That chaste and virtuous woman, that preserved me,
That pious wife, wedded to my afflictions,
Must be more terrible than all my dangers.
O fortune, thou hast robbed men of my making,
The noble building of a man, demolished,
And flung me headlong, on a sin so base
Man and mankind contemn; even beasts abhor it,
A sin more dull than drink, a shame beyond it;
So foul, and far from faith; I dare not name it,
But it will cry itself out, loud ingratitude.
Your blessing Sir.
You have it in abundance;
So is our joy, to see you safe.
My Dear one;
He has not forgot me yet: O take me to you Sir.
Must this be added to increase my misery,
That she must weep for joy, and lose that goodness?
My Iuliana, even the best of women,
Of wives the perfectest, let me speak this,
And with a modesty declare thy virtues,
Chaster than Crystal, on the Scythian Cliffs
The more the proud winds Court, the more the purer.
Sweeter in thy obedience, than a sacrifice;
And in thy mind a Saint, that even yet living,
Producest miracles, and women daily
With crooked and tame souls creep to thy goodness,
Which having touched at, they become examples.
The fortitude of all their sex, is Fable
Compared to thine; and they that filled up glory,
And admiration, in the age behind us,
Out of their celebrated urns, are started,
To stare upon the greatness of thy spirit;
Wondering what new Martyr heaven has begot,
To fill the times with truth, and ease their stories:
Being all these, and excellent in Beauty,
(For noble things dwell in the noblest buildings)
Thou hast undone thy husband, made him wretched,
A miserable man, my Iuliana,
Thou hast made thy Virolet.
Now goodness keep me;
O! my dear Lord.
She wrong you? what is the meaning!
Weep not, but speak, I charge you on obedience;
Your Father charges you, she make you miserable?
That you yourself confess.
I do, that kills me;
And far less I have spoke her, than her merit.
It is some sin of weakness, or of Ignorance?
For sure my Will --
No, it is a sin of excellence:
Forgive me heaven, that I profane thy blessings:
Sit still; I will show you all.
What means this madness?
For sure there is no taste of right man in it;
Grieves he our liberty, our preservation?
Or has the greatness of the deed he has done,
Made him forget, for whom, and how he did it,
And looking down upon us, scorn the benefit?
Well Virolet if thou beest proud, or treacherous
He cannot Sir, he cannot; he will show us,
And with that reason ground his words.
He comes.
What Masque is this? what admirable beauty?
Pray heaven his heart be true.
A goodly woman.
Tell me my Dear; and tell me without flattery,
As you are nobly honest, speak the truth;
What think you of this Lady?
She is most excellent.
Might not this beauty tell me that it is a sweet one,
Without more setting off, as now it is,
Thanking no greater Mistress than mere nature?
Stagger a constant heart?
She is full of wonder,
But yet; yet Virolet.
Pray; by your leave Sir.
She would amaze:
O! would she so? I thank you;
Say to this beauty, she have all additions,
Wealth, noble birth.
O hold there.
All virtues,
A mind, as full of Candour as the truth is,
Aye, and a loving Lady.
She must needs
(I am bound in conscience to confess) deserve much.
Nay, say beyond all these, she be so pious,
That even on slaves condemned she shower her benefits,
And melt their stubborn Bolts with her soft pity,
What think you then?
For such a noble office,
At these years, I should dote myself; take heed Boy,
If you be he, that have received these blessings,
And this the Lady: love her, honour her;
You cannot do too much, to show your gratitude,
Your greatest service will show off too slender.
This is the Lady; Lady of that bounty,
That wealth, that noble name, that all I spoke of:
The Prince Ascaino and myself, the slaves
Redeemed, brought home, still guarded by her goodness,
And of our liberties you taste the sweetness;
Even you she has preserved too, lengthened your lives.
And what reward do you purpose? it must be a main one;
If love will do it we will all, so love her, serve her.
It must be my love.
Ha!
Mine, my only love,
My everlasting love:
How?
Pray have patience.
The recompense she asked, and I have rendered.
Was to become her husband: then I vowed it,
And since I have made it good.
Thou durst not.
Done Sir.
Be what you please, his happiness yet stays with me,
You have been mine; O my unhappy fortune.
Nay, break and die;
It cannot yet: I must live,
Till I see this man, blessed in his new love,
And then:
What hast thou done? thou base one tell me,
Thou barren thing of honesty, and honour;
What hast thou wrought? Is not this she, look on her,
Look on her, with the eyes of gratitude,
And whip thy false tears off; Is not this she,
That three times on the Rack, to guard thy safety,
When thou stoodest lost, and naked to the Tyrant;
Thy aged Father here, that shames to know thee Tyrant,
Engaged in the jaws of danger; was not this she,
That then gave up her body to the torture?
That tender body, that the wind sings through;
And three times, when her sinews, cracked and tortured,
The beauties of her body turned to ruins,
Even then, within her patient heart, she locked thee;
Then hid thee from the Tyrant; then preserved thee;
And canst thou be that slave?
This was but duty;
She did it for her Husband, and she ought it;
She has had the pleasure of him, many an hour;
And if one minutes pain cannot be suffered;
Mine was above all these, a nobler venture,
I speak it boldly, for I lost a Father.
He has one still; I left my friends, he has many;
Exposed my life, and honour to a cruelty,
That if it had seized on me, racks and tortures,
Alas, they are Triumphs to it: and had it hit,
For this man's love, it should have showed a triumph,
Twice lost, I freed him; Rossana lost before him,
His fortunes with him; and his friends behind him:
Twice was I racked myself for his deliverance,
In honour first and name, which was a torture
The Hang-man never heard of; next at Sea,
In our escape, where the proud waves took pleasure
To toss my little Boat up like a Bubble,
Then like meteor in the air he hung,
Then catched, and hug him in the depth of darkness;
The Canon from my incensed Fathers Ship,
Ringing our Knell, and still as we peeped upward,
Beating the raging surge, with fire and Bullet,
And I stood fixed for this man's sake, and scorned it;
Compare but this:
It is too true; O my fortune!
That I must equally be bound to either:
You have the better, and the nobler Lady;
And now I am forced, a lover of her goodness.
And so far have you wrought for his deliverance,
That is my Lord, so lovingly and nobly,
That now methinks I stagger in my Title.
But how with honesty? for I am poor Lady,
In all my duteous service but your shadow,
Yet would be just; how with fair fame and credit,
I may go off; I would not be a strumpet:
O my dear Sir you know:
O truth, thou knowest too.
Nor have the world suspect, I fell to mischief.
Take you no care for that, here is that has don it,
A fair divorce, it is honest too.
The devil,
Honest? to put her off.
Most honest Sir,
And in this point, most strong.
The cause, the cause Sir?
A just cause too.
As any is in hell, Lawyer.
For barrenness, she never brought him children.
Why art not thou divorced? thou canst not get them;
Thy neighbours, thy rank neighbours: O base juggling,
Is she not young?
Women at more years Sir,
Have met that blessing; it is in heavens high power.
You never can have any:
Why quick Lawyer?
My Philosophical Lawyer.
The RAck has spoiled her
The distentions of those parts, hath stopped all fruitfulness.
O I could curse.
And am I grown so miserable,
That mine own pity must make me wretched?
No cause against me, but my love and duty?
Farewell Sir; like obedience, thus I leave you,
My long farewell: I do not grudge, I grieve Sir,
And if that be offensive, I can die,
And then you fairly free: good Lady love him;
You have a noble, and an honest Gentleman,
I ever found him so, the world has spoke him;
And let it be your part still to deserve him:
Love him no less than I have done; and serve him,
And heaven shall bless you; you shall bless my ashes;
I give you up the house; the name of wife,
Honour, and all respect I borrowed from him,
And to my grave I turn: one farewell more,
Nothing divide your Loves, not want of Children,
Which I shall pray against, and make you fruitful;
Grow like two equal flames, rise high and glorious;
And in your honoured age, burn out together:
To all I know, farewell.
Be not so grieved Lady;
A nobler fortune.
Away thou parasite.
Disturb not my sad thoughts; I hate thy greatness.
I hate not you; I am glad she is off these hinges,
Come, let us pursue.
If I had breath to curse thee;
Or could my great heart utter; farewell villain,
Thy house, nor face again.
Let them all go.
And now let us rejoice; now freely take me,
And now embrace me Virolet; give the rites
Of a brave Husband to his love.
I will take my leave too.
How, take you leave too?
The house is furnished for you;
You are Mistress, may command.
Will you to bed Sir?
As soon to hell, to anything I hate most;
You must excuse me, I have kept my word.
You are my wife, you now enjoy my fortune,
Which I have done to recompense your bounty:
But to yield up those chaste delights and pleasures,
Which are not mine, but my first vows.
You jest.
You will not find it so, to give you those;
I have divorced, and lost with Iuliana,
And all fires of that nature.
Are you a Husband;
To question hers, and satisfy your flames,
That held an equal beauty, equal bounty.
Good heaven forgive; no, no, the strict forbearance,
Of all those joys, like a full sacrifice,
I offer to the sufferings of my first love;
Honour, and wealth, attendance, state, all duty,
Shall wait upon your will, to make you happy;
But my afflicted mind, you must give leave Lady;
My weary Trunk must wander.
Not enjoy me?
Go from me too?
For ever thus I leave you;
And howsoever I fare, live you still happy.
Since I am scorned, I will hate thee, scorn thy gifts too;
Thou miserable fool, thou fool to pity;
And such a rude, demolished thing, I will leave thee,
In my revenge: for foolish love, farewell now,
And anger, and the spite of woman enter,
That all the world shall say, that read this story,
My hate, and not my love, begot my glory.
He that fears death, or tortures, let him leave me.
The stops that we have met with, Crown our Conquest:
Common attempts are fit for common men;
The rare, the rarest spirits. Can we be daunted?
We that have smiled at Sea at certain ruins,
Which men on shore; but hazarded would shake at
We that have lived free, in despite of fortune,
Laughed at the outstretched Arm of Tyranny,
As still too short to reach us, shall we faint now?
No my brave mates, I know your fiery temper,
And that you can, and dare, as much as men:
Calamity, that severs worldly friendships,
Could never divide us, you are still the same;
The constant followers of my banished fortunes;
The Instruments of my revenge; the hands
By which I work, and fashion all my projects.
And such we will be ever.
'Slight Sir, Cram me
Into a Canons mouth, and shoot me at
Proud Ferrands head; may only he fall with me,
My life I rate at nothing.
Could I but get,
Within my swords length of him; and if then
He scape me, may the account of all his sins
Be added unto mine.
It is not to die Sir,
But to die unrevenged, that staggers me:
For were your ends served, and our Country free,
We would fall willing sacrifices.
To rise up,
Most glorious Martyrs.
But the reason why
We wear these shapes?
Only to get access:
Like honest men, we never shall approach him,
Such are his fears, but thus attired like Switzers,
And fashioning our language to our habits;
Bold, bloody, desperate, we may be admitted
Among his guard. But if this fail, I will try
A thousand others, outdo Proteus
In various shapes, but I will reach his heart.
And seal my anger on it.
The Lord Ronero.
Shall we begin with him?
He is not ripe yet,
Nor fit to fall: as you see me begin,
With mall care imitate.
We are instructed.
Would we were at it once.
Keep a strict watch,
And let the guards be doubled; this last night
The King had fearful dreams.
It is a good Omen
To our attempts.
What men are these? What seek you?
Employment.
Of what nature?
We are Soldiers;
We have seen towns and Churches set on fire;
The Kennels running blood, coy virgins ravished;
The Altars ransacked, and the holy relics,
Yea, and the Saints themselves, made lawful spoils,
Unto the Conquerors: but these good days are past,
And we made Beggars, by this Idle Peace,
For want of action. I am Sir no stranger
To the Government of this state, I know the King
Needs men, that only do what he commands,
And search no further: it is the profession
Of all our Nation, to serve faithfully,
Where they are best payed: and if you entertain us,
I do not know the thing you can command,
Which we will not put in act.
A goodly Patronage.
And if you have an Enemy, or so
That you would have despatched.
They are here, can fit you.
Or if there be an Itch, though to a man,
You shall tie
Our consciences in your purse-strings.
Gentlemen,
I like your freedom: I am now in haste,
But wait for my return. I like the Rascals,
They may be useful.
We will attend you Sir:
Do; and be confident of entertainment;
I hope ye will deserve it.
O, no doubt Sir:
Thus far we are prosperous; we will be his guard,
Till Tyranny and pride find full reward:
My blessing? no; a Fathers heavy curse,
Pursue, and overtake him.
Gentle Sir.
My name, and Family; and in myself
Rather than live in him.
Dear Sir forbear,
A fathers curses hit far off, and kill too,
And like a murthering-piece aims not at one,
But all that stand within the dangerous level.
Some bullet may return upon yourself too,
Though against nature, if you still go on
In this unnatural course.
Thou art not made
Of that same stuff as other women are:
Thy injuries would teach patience to blaspheme;
Yet still thou art a Dove.
I know not malice, but like an innocent, suffer.
More miraculous!
I will have a woman Chronicled, and for goodness,
Which is the greatest wonder. Let me see,
I have no son to inherit after me;
Him I disclaim.
What then? I will make thy virtues my sole heir;
Thy story I will have written, and in Gold too;
In prose and verse, and by the ablest doers:
A word or two of a kind step-father
I will have put in, good Kings and Queens shall buy it.
And if the actions of ill great women,
And of the modern times too, are remembered,
That have undone their husbands, and their families,
What will our story do? It shall be so,
And I will straight about it.
Such as love
Goodness for glory, have it for reward;
I love mine for itself: let innocence
Be written on my Tomb, though never so humble,
It is all I am ambitious of. But I
Forget my vows.
Before me, you are not modest,
Nor is this Court-like. Would you take it well,
If she should rudely press into your Closet,
When from your several Boxes you choose paint,
To make a this days face with?
What is the matter?
Pray know her pleasure first.
To whom speak you Boy?
Your Ladyships pardon. That proud Lady thief,
That stole away my Lord from your embraces,
